content: The Act may be cited as the "Agricultural Energy Programs Reauthorization Act of 2017". The Act includes a section on the Biobased Markets Program. Section 9002 of the Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 is amended to include renewable chemicals in the biobased products labeling program. The Secretary will provide education and outreach to stakeholders. Manufacturers of renewable chemicals and biobased products will be classified under specific NAICS codes. The amendment includes the addition of renewable chemicals to the biobased products labeling program. Manufacturers of renewable chemicals and biobased products will be classified under specific NAICS codes. The Secretary will also establish a national testing center registry and report on the quantity of biobased products procured annually. Funding for the program will be adjusted for fiscal years 2014 through 2018. In subsection (i), funding for the program will be increased to $6,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2019 through 2023. In subsection (j), the program now includes products produced from biologically captured and reused carbon. SEC. 3. Assistance for biorefinery, renewable chemical, and biobased product manufacturing. Section 9003 of the Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 is amended to provide mandatory funding for loan guarantees for renewable chemical, biobased product, and biorefinery projects. $75,000,000 is allocated annually from 2019 to 2023 for this purpose. SEC. 4. BIOENERGY PROGRAM FOR ADVANCED BIOFUELS. Amends Section 9005(g) of the Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 to allocate $5,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2018 to 2023. Amends Section 9003 to provide mandatory funding for loan guarantees for renewable chemical, biobased product, and biorefinery projects, with $75,000,000 allocated annually from 2019 to 2023. The definition of a renewable energy system is expanded to include distribution components and ancillary infrastructure. Funding for renewable energy projects is also amended to allocate resources accordingly. Funding for renewable energy projects is amended to allocate $150,000,000 annually from 2018 to 2023. Additionally, $50,000,000 will be allocated for each fiscal year from 2018 to 2023 for technologies to improve energy efficiency, with a limit of 30% for each fiscal year. SEC. 6. Biomass research and development funding is increased to $20,000,000 annually from 2019 to 2023. SEC. 7. The Feedstock Flexibility Program for bioenergy producers is extended to 2023. SEC. 8. The Biofuels and Biobased Product Feedstock and Wildland Fire Protection Program continues. The Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 is amended to include a biofuels and biobased product feedstock and wildland fire protection program. This involves redesignating paragraphs and making adjustments to the program details. The amendments involve adding clauses related to algae, animal waste, and byproducts, as well as redesignating existing clauses within the program. The amendments involve adding clauses related to algae, animal waste, and byproducts, as well as redesignating existing clauses within the program. The program definition is clarified, and changes are made to project areas and eligible materials for hazardous woody fuel reduction. The amendments to the Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 include changes to the Biofuels and Biobased Product Feedstock and Wildland Fire Protection Program. Amendments involve removing references to BCAP, clarifying program definitions, and specifying eligible materials for hazardous woody fuel reduction in project areas. The amendments to the Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 involve inserting "program" before "contract" and "payments on land" in certain paragraphs, redesignating paragraphs, and allowing for hazardous woody fuel reduction projects to receive payments for transportation costs. The Secretary may provide payments for transportation costs of projects removing eligible material for hazardous woody fuel reduction in wildland areas at risk from wildfire or in need of restoration, prioritizing projects that offer the greatest benefit to human life and structures. The Secretary may provide payments for transportation costs of projects removing eligible material for hazardous woody fuel reduction in wildland areas at risk from wildfire or in need of restoration. Projects will prioritize the protection of human life, structures in the wildland-urban interface, and municipal water supplies. Producers must leave uncollected and unharvested at least 30 percent of woody eligible material. In subsection (f), mandatory funding of $70,000,000 from the Commodity Credit Corporation funds for fiscal years 2019 through 2023, and discretionary funding of $20,000,000 for each of those years, are authorized for the Secretary to carry out the program. The Secretary is authorized to use funding for hazardous woody fuel reduction projects, with a minimum of $50,000,000 allocated for transportation payments. The Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 is amended to extend the Community Wood Energy Program until 2023. The effective date for these amendments is October 1, 2018.
